cards.title: Wimbledon 2015 / In pictures: how the punters are dealing with the heat
cards.rawTitle: In pictures: how the punters are dealing with the heat

item.title: Wimbledon 2015: feeling hot, hot, hot – in pictures!
item.trailText: With temperatures soaring in SW19, Guardian photographer Graeme Robertson checks out how the punters are dealing with the heat
item.standFirst: With record-breaking temperatures across the UK, Guardian photographer Graeme Robertson checks out how the punters are dealing with the heat

cards.title: Women's World Cup / Bassett’s mother: it was hard to see her cry
cards.rawTitle: Bassett’s mother: it was hard to see her cry

item.title: Laura Bassett’s mother: it was hard to see her cry
item.trailText: The mother of Laura Bassett says it was tough to watch her daughter cry after scoring the injury-time own-goal that cost England a place in the World Cup final
item.standFirst: The mother of Laura Bassett says it was tough to watch her daughter cry after scoring the injury-time own-goal that cost England a place in the World Cup final. Speaking to ITV News Central, Marie Bassett says it was a 'surreal moment', but she is confident Laura will 'bounce back'. The defender was in tears after slicing an intended clearance into her own net in the 2-1 defeat to Japan

stillImage.caption: 620x372 trailpic for England footballer mother Photograph: guardian.co.uk

cards.title: Ashes / A roundup of England's 13-man Ashes squad
cards.rawTitle: A roundup of England's 13-man Ashes squad

item.title: England's Ashes Squad
item.trailText: We round up the England team to face Australia in the Ashes
item.standFirst: We round up the England team to face Australia in the Ashes

displayImages.caption:
Alastair Cook
Age 30
Caps 114
County Essex
Previous Ashes 2006-07, 2009, 2010-11, 2013, 2013-14

England’s captain and also their leading all-time Test run-scorer. In the 2010-11 Ashes in Australia he scored 766 runs at an average of 127, but also led the side in their whitewash defeat 18 months ago. Photograph: Laurence Griffiths/Getty Images
displayImages.altText:
Alastair Cook
Age 30
Caps 114
County Essex
Previous Ashes 2006-07, 2009, 2010-11, 2013, 2013-14
England’s captain and also their leading all-time Test run-scorer. In the 2010-11 Ashes in Austrlia he scored 766 runs at an average of 127, but led the side to their whitewash defeat 18 months ago
displayImages.cleanCaption:
Alastair Cook
Age 30
Caps 114
County Essex
Previous Ashes 2006-07, 2009, 2010-11, 2013, 2013-14

England’s captain and also their leading all-time Test run-scorer. In the 2010-11 Ashes in Australia he scored 766 runs at an average of 127, but also led the side in their whitewash defeat 18 months ago.

displayImages.caption:
Moeen Ali
Age 28
Caps 11
County Worcestershire
Previous Ashes Debutant

Named one of Wisden’s Cricketers of the Year after an impressive 2014. The left-handed batsman made his debut against Sri Lanka at Lord’s last summer and scored a century in his second match. In the series that followed against India he took 19 wickets with his off-spin. Has not enjoyed quite the same success this summer and still has some way to go to be a leading Test match spinner. Photograph: Paul Ellis/AFP/Getty Images
displayImages.altText:
Moeen Ali
Age 28
Caps 11
Worcestershire
Ashes debutant
Named one of Wisden’s Cricketers of the Year after an impressive 2014. The left-handed batsman made his debut against Sri Lanka at Lord’s last summer and scored a century in his second match. In the series that followed against India he took 19 wickets with his off-spin. Has not enjoyed quite the same success this summer and still has some way to go to be a leading Test match spinner
displayImages.cleanCaption:
Moeen Ali
Age 28
Caps 11
County Worcestershire
Previous Ashes Debutant

Named one of Wisden’s Cricketers of the Year after an impressive 2014. The left-handed batsman made his debut against Sri Lanka at Lord’s last summer and scored a century in his second match. In the series that followed against India he took 19 wickets with his off-spin. Has not enjoyed quite the same success this summer and still has some way to go to be a leading Test match spinner.

displayImages.caption:
James Anderson
Age 32
Caps 102
County Lancashire
Previous Ashes 2006-7, 2009, 2010-11, 2013, 2013-14

England’s most experienced bowler and one of the best swingers of the ball in the world. Became England’s leading Test wicket-taker in the Caribbean earlier this year and then went past 400 wickets in the series against New Zealand. Considered by many Australians as England’s biggest sledger. Photograph: Stu Forster/Getty Images
displayImages.altText:
James Anderson
Age 32
Caps 102
Lancashire
Previous Ashes 2006-7, 2009, 2010-11, 2013, 2013-14
England’s most experienced bowler and one of the best swingers of the ball in the world. Became England’s leading Test wicket-taker in the Caribbean earlier this year and then went past 400 wickets in the series against New Zealand. Seen by many Australians as England’s biggest sledger
displayImages.cleanCaption:
James Anderson
Age 32
Caps 102
County Lancashire
Previous Ashes 2006-7, 2009, 2010-11, 2013, 2013-14

England’s most experienced bowler and one of the best swingers of the ball in the world. Became England’s leading Test wicket-taker in the Caribbean earlier this year and then went past 400 wickets in the series against New Zealand. Considered by many Australians as England’s biggest sledger.

displayImages.caption:
Gary Ballance
Age 25
Caps 13
County Yorkshire
Previous Ashes 2013-14

Made his debut in the final Test of the 5-0 defeat in 2013-14 and has been a fixture since. An impressive record in his 13 Tests with a batting average of over 50, but his technique was brought into question by the New Zealand left-arm quick Trent Boult earlier this summer. Photograph: Ricardo Mazalan/AP
displayImages.altText:
Gary Ballance
Age 25
Caps 13
County Yorkshire
Previous Ashes 2013-14
Made his debut in the final Test of the 5-0 defeat in 2013-14 and has been a fixture since. An impressive record in his 13 Tests with a batting average of over 50, but his technique was brought into question by the New Zealand left-arm quick Trent Boult earlier this summer.
displayImages.cleanCaption:
Gary Ballance
Age 25
Caps 13
County Yorkshire
Previous Ashes 2013-14

Made his debut in the final Test of the 5-0 defeat in 2013-14 and has been a fixture since. An impressive record in his 13 Tests with a batting average of over 50, but his technique was brought into question by the New Zealand left-arm quick Trent Boult earlier this summer.

displayImages.caption:
Ian Bell
Age 33
Caps 110
County Warwickshire
Previous Ashes 2005, 2006-07, 2009, 2010-11, 2013, 2013-14

Has struggled for runs since scoring a century in the first Test in the Caribbean. Was England’s best batsmen when they defeated the Australians at home two years ago and there are few finer cricketing sights than Bell in full flow. Photograph: Michael Steele/Getty Images
displayImages.altText:
Ian Bell
Age 33
Caps 110
Warwickshire
Previous Ashes 2005, 2006-07, 2009, 2010-11, 2013, 2013-14
Has struggled for runs since scoring a century in the first Test in the Caribbean. Was England’s best batsmen when they defeated the Australians at home two years ago and there’s arguably no finer sight than Bell in full flow.
displayImages.cleanCaption:
Ian Bell
Age 33
Caps 110
County Warwickshire
Previous Ashes 2005, 2006-07, 2009, 2010-11, 2013, 2013-14

Has struggled for runs since scoring a century in the first Test in the Caribbean. Was England’s best batsmen when they defeated the Australians at home two years ago and there are few finer cricketing sights than Bell in full flow.

displayImages.caption:
Stuart Broad
Age 29
Caps 79
County Nottinghamshire
Previous Ashes 2009, 2010-11, 2013, 2013-14

Once viewed as an all-rounder but his batting skills have dipped alarmingly. Along with James Anderson, will lead England’s pace attack. Was England’s leading bowler in their 2009 Ashes win with 18 wickets. Photograph: Laurence Griffiths/Getty Images
displayImages.altText:
Stuart Broad
Age 29
Caps 79
Nottinghamshire
Previous Ashes 2009, 2010-11, 2013, 2013-14
Once viewed as an all-rounder but his batting skills have dipped alarmingly. But, along with James Anderson, will lead England’s pace attack. Was England’s leading bowler in their 2009 Ashes win with 18 wickets.
displayImages.cleanCaption:
Stuart Broad
Age 29
Caps 79
County Nottinghamshire
Previous Ashes 2009, 2010-11, 2013, 2013-14

Once viewed as an all-rounder but his batting skills have dipped alarmingly. Along with James Anderson, will lead England’s pace attack. Was England’s leading bowler in their 2009 Ashes win with 18 wickets.

displayImages.caption:
Jos Buttler
Age 24
Caps 8
County Lancashire
Previous Ashes Debutant

Once seen as a one-day wicketkeeper-batsman specialist, but now destined to keep the gloves in the Test arena for years to come. A truly destructive batsman in the Adam Gilchrist mould, though still room to improve his keeping skills. Photograph: Philip Brown/Reuters
displayImages.altText:
Jos Buttler
Age 24
Caps 8
Lancashire
Ashes debutantOnce seen as a one-day wicket-keeper-batsman specialist, but now destined to keep the gloves in the Test arena for years to come. A truly destructive batsman in the Adam Gilchrist mould, though does need to improve his keeping skills
displayImages.cleanCaption:
Jos Buttler
Age 24
Caps 8
County Lancashire
Previous Ashes Debutant

Once seen as a one-day wicketkeeper-batsman specialist, but now destined to keep the gloves in the Test arena for years to come. A truly destructive batsman in the Adam Gilchrist mould, though still room to improve his keeping skills.

displayImages.caption:
Steven Finn
Age 26
Caps 23
County Middlesex
Previous Ashes 2010-11, 2013

Went on England’s tour in 2013-14 but didn’t play in one Test, and played just one Test in the winning series at home months earlier. Made his England debut five years ago but has never held down a regular place. Will likely battle with Mark Wood for the third seamer’s position. Photograph: Gareth Copley/Getty Images
displayImages.altText:
Steven Finn
Age 26
Caps 23
Middlesex
Previous Ashes 2010-11, 2013
Went on England’s tour in 2013-14 but didn’t play in one Test despite the 5-0 defeat and had played just one game in the winning series in England months earlier. Made his England debut five years ago but has never held down a regular place. Will likely battle with Mark Wood for the third seamer’s position.
displayImages.cleanCaption:
Steven Finn
Age 26
Caps 23
County Middlesex
Previous Ashes 2010-11, 2013

Went on England’s tour in 2013-14 but didn’t play in one Test, and played just one Test in the winning series at home months earlier. Made his England debut five years ago but has never held down a regular place. Will likely battle with Mark Wood for the third seamer’s position.

displayImages.caption:
Adam Lyth
Age 27
Caps 2
County Yorkshire
Previous Ashes Debutant

Was selected on the tour of West Indies earlier this year after a stack of runs in county cricket, but kicked his heels in the Caribbean as England opted for Jonathan Trott at the top of the order. However, played in both Tests against New Zealand, scoring a century in the second one at Headingley, his home ground. Photograph: David Rogers/Getty Images
displayImages.altText:
Adam Lyth
Age 27
Caps 2
County Yorkshire
Ashes debutant
Was selected on the tour of West Indies earlier this year after a stack of runs in county cricket, but kicked his heels in the Caribbean as England opted for Jonathan Trott at the top of the order. However, played in both Tests against New Zealand, scoring a century in the second one at Headingley, his home ground
displayImages.cleanCaption:
Adam Lyth
Age 27
Caps 2
County Yorkshire
Previous Ashes Debutant

Was selected on the tour of West Indies earlier this year after a stack of runs in county cricket, but kicked his heels in the Caribbean as England opted for Jonathan Trott at the top of the order. However, played in both Tests against New Zealand, scoring a century in the second one at Headingley, his home ground.

displayImages.caption:
Adil Rashid
Age 27
Caps 0
County Yorkshire
Previous Ashes Debutant

Like his county colleague Adam Lyth, leg-spinner Rashid was selected for the tour of the Caribbean earlier this year but didn’t play in the Tests, a decision criticsed by many. He was overlooked, in favour of Moeen Ali, for the two Test series against New Zealand and also didn’t figure in England’s pre-Ashes training camp in Spain at the end of June. Can give the ball a rip but is also prone to bowling too many boundary balls. Photograph: Laurence Griffiths/Getty Images
displayImages.altText:
Adil Rashid

Caps 0
Yorkshire
Ashes debutant
Like his county colleague Adam Lyth, leg-spinner Rashid was selected for the tour of the Caribbean earlier this year but didn’t play in the Tests, a decision criticsed by many. displayImages.caption:
Joe Root
Age 24
Caps 27
County Yorkshire
Previous Ashes 2013, 2013-14

Appointed as vice-captain at the start of the summer and immediately went on to score 98 and 84 in the first Test against New Zealand. A gritty Yorkshireman who will be determined to improve on his one Test century against Australia. Photograph: Jewel Samad/AFP/Getty Images
displayImages.altText:
Joe Root
Age 24

Yorkshire

displayImages.caption:
Ben Stokes
Age 24
Caps 11
County Durham
Previous Ashes 2013-14

The all-rounder was seen as one of the only successes of England’s tour to Australia 18 months ago. Made his debut in the second Test in Adelaide and in the third in Perth scored his maiden Test century. Has already lit up England’s summer by scoring the fastest ever Test century at Lord’s against New Zealand. Photograph: John Walton/PA
displayImages.altText:

Age 25
Caps 2
County Durham
Previous Ashes Debutant

The right-arm paceman from Ashington made his debut against New Zealand at Lord’s in May and has nine wickets in his two matches. The one England bowler who appears to be able to bowl around 90mph with regularity. Photograph: Gareth Copley/Getty Images

Has struggled for runs since scoring a century in the first Test in the Caribbean. Was England’s best batsmen when they defeated the Australians at home two years ago and there’s arguably no finer sight than Bell in full flow.
image.cleanCaption:
Ian Bell
Age 33
Caps 110
County Warwickshire
Previous Ashes 2005, 2006-07, 2009, 2010-11, 2013, 2013-14

Has struggled for runs since scoring a century in the first Test in the Caribbean. Was England’s best batsmen when they defeated the Australians at home two years ago and there are few finer cricketing sights than Bell in full flow.

image.caption:
Stuart Broad
Age 29
Caps 79
County Nottinghamshire
Previous Ashes 2009, 2010-11, 2013, 2013-14

Once viewed as an all-rounder but his batting skills have dipped alarmingly. Along with James Anderson, will lead England’s pace attack. Was England’s leading bowler in their 2009 Ashes win with 18 wickets. Photograph: Laurence Griffiths/Getty Images
image.altText:
Stuart Broad
Age 29
Caps 79

Once viewed as an all-rounder but his batting skills have dipped alarmingly. Along with James Anderson, will lead England’s pace attack. Was England’s leading bowler in their 2009 Ashes win with 18 wickets.

image.caption:
Jos Buttler
Age 24
Caps 8
County Lancashire
Previous Ashes Debutant

Once seen as a one-day wicketkeeper-batsman specialist, but now destined to keep the gloves in the Test arena for years to come. A truly destructive batsman in the Adam Gilchrist mould, though still room to improve his keeping skills. Photograph: Philip Brown/Reuters
image.altText:
Jos Buttler
Age 24
Caps 8
Lancashire
Ashes debutantOnce seen as a one-day wicket-keeper-batsman specialist, but now destined to keep the gloves in the Test arena for years to come. A truly destructive batsman in the Adam Gilchrist mould, though does need to improve his keeping skills
image.cleanCaption:

Age 24
Caps 8
County Lancashire
Previous Ashes Debutant

Once seen as a one-day wicketkeeper-batsman specialist, but now destined to keep the gloves in the Test arena for years to come. A truly destructive batsman in the Adam Gilchrist mould, though still room to improve his keeping skills.

image.caption:
Steven Finn
Age 26
Caps 23
County Middlesex
Previous Ashes 2010-11, 2013

Went on England’s tour in 2013-14 but didn’t play in one Test, and played just one Test in the winning series at home months earlier. Made his England debut five years ago but has never held down a regular place. Will likely battle with Mark Wood for the third seamer’s position. Photograph: Gareth Copley/Getty Images
image.altText:
Steven Finn
Age 26
Caps 23
Middlesex
Previous Ashes 2010-11, 2013
Went on England’s tour in 2013-14 but didn’t play in one Test despite the 5-0 defeat and had played just one game in the winning series in England months earlier. Made his England debut five years ago but has never held down a regular place. Will likely battle with Mark Wood for the third seamer’s position.
image.cleanCaption:
Steven Finn
Age 26
Caps 23
County Middlesex
Previous Ashes 2010-11, 2013

Went on England’s tour in 2013-14 but didn’t play in one Test, and played just one Test in the winning series at home months earlier. Made his England debut five years ago but has never held down a regular place. Will likely battle with Mark Wood for the third seamer’s position.

image.caption:
Adam Lyth
Age 27
Caps 2
County Yorkshire
Previous Ashes Debutant

Was selected on the tour of West Indies earlier this year after a stack of runs in county cricket, but kicked his heels in the Caribbean as England opted for Jonathan Trott at the top of the order. However, played in both Tests against New Zealand, scoring a century in the second one at Headingley, his home ground. Photograph: David Rogers/Getty Images
image.altText:
Adam Lyth
Age 27
Caps 2

image.caption:
Adil Rashid
Age 27
Caps 0
County Yorkshire
Previous Ashes Debutant

Like his county colleague Adam Lyth, leg-spinner Rashid was selected for the tour of the Caribbean earlier this year but didn’t play in the Tests, a decision criticsed by many. He was overlooked, in favour of Moeen Ali, for the two Test series against New Zealand and also didn’t figure in England’s pre-Ashes training camp in Spain at the end of June. Can give the ball a rip but is also prone to bowling too many boundary balls. Photograph: Laurence Griffiths/Getty Images

Appointed as vice-captain at the start of the summer and immediately went on to score 98 and 84 in the first Test against New Zealand. A gritty Yorkshireman who will be determined to improve on his one Test century against Australia. Photograph: Jewel Samad/AFP/Getty Images

Ben Stokes

The all-rounder was seen as one of the only successes of England’s tour to Australia 18 months ago. Made his debut in the second Test in Adelaide and in the third in Perth scored his maiden Test century. Has already lit up England’s summer by scoring the fastest ever Test century at Lord’s against New Zealand. Photograph: John Walton/PA

The right-arm paceman from Ashington made his debut against New Zealand at Lord’s in May and has nine wickets in his two matches. The one England bowler who appears to be able to bowl around 90mph with regularity. Photograph: Gareth Copley/Getty Images

cards.title: In pictures / Japan beat England in the semi-final of the Women's World Cup
cards.rawTitle: Japan beat England in the semi-final of the Women's World Cup

item.title: Women's World Cup: Japan beat England
item.trailText: The first senior England team to reach a World Cup semi-final since 1990 take on the defending champions. Here are the best photos of the match
item.standFirst:
They were the first senior England team to reach an World Cup semi-final since Lineker and co in 1990. But, like their predecessors, they fell agonisingly short as an injury-time goal from Japan knocked them out of the tournament. Here are the best photos of the match
• Read the match report
• Japan beat England 1-0 – as it happened

displayImages.caption: The players emerge before the match, with England’s Laura Bassett and Fara Williams in white. Photograph: Maddie Meyer/Fifa via Getty Images
displayImages.altText: The players emerge before the match, with England’s Laura Bassett and Fara Williams in white.
displayImages.cleanCaption: The players emerge before the match, with England’s Laura Bassett and Fara Williams in white.
displayImages.cleanCredit: Photograph: Maddie Meyer/Fifa via Getty Images

displayImages.caption: The sun’s beating down while the players and the crowd, which is the second highest in the competition thus far, sing the national anthems. Photograph: Kevin C. Cox/Getty Images
displayImages.altText: The sun’s beating down while the players and the crowd, which is the second highest in the competition thus far, sing the national anthems.
displayImages.cleanCaption: The sun’s beating down while the players and the crowd, which is the second highest in the competition thus far, sing the national anthems.

displayImages.caption: England defender Laura Bassett gets stuck in as Japan forward Mana Iwabuchi tries to evade her. Photograph: Erich Schlegel/USA Today Sports
displayImages.altText: England defender Laura Bassett gets stuck in as Japan forward Mana Iwabuchi tries to evade her.
displayImages.cleanCaption: England defender Laura Bassett gets stuck in as Japan forward Mana Iwabuchi tries to evade her.

displayImages.caption: Japan’s Rumi Utsugi (wearing 13) is a menace. She’s pictured shielding the ball from Katie Chapman. Photograph: Jeff McIntosh/AP
displayImages.altText: Japan’s Rumi Utsugi (wearing 13) is a menace. She’s pictured shielding the ball from Katie Chapman.
displayImages.cleanCaption: Japan’s Rumi Utsugi (wearing 13) is a menace. She’s pictured shielding the ball from Katie Chapman.

displayImages.caption: In the 32nd minute, Claire Rafferty gets the wrong side of Saori Ariyoshi of Japan and, in her desperation, shoves the Japanese player in the back ... Photograph: Matthew Lewis/Fifa via Getty Images
displayImages.altText: In the 32nd minute, Claire Rafferty gets the wrong side of Saori Ariyoshi of Japan and, in her desperation, shoves the Japanese player in the back ...
displayImages.cleanCaption: In the 32nd minute, Claire Rafferty gets the wrong side of Saori Ariyoshi of Japan and, in her desperation, shoves the Japanese player in the back ...
displayImages.cleanCredit: Photograph: Matthew Lewis/Fifa via Getty Images

displayImages.caption: Ariyoshi goes down, but was the contact inside the box or out? The referee says inside, so Japan have a penalty. Photograph: Kevin C. Cox/Getty Images
displayImages.altText: Ariyoshi goes down to win a penalty
displayImages.cleanCaption: Ariyoshi goes down, but was the contact inside the box or out? The referee says inside, so Japan have a penalty.

displayImages.caption: England’s goalkeeper Karen Bardsley is sent the wrong way by Aya Miyama, who took an eternity to strike her shot. Photograph: Mike Hewitt/Fifa via Getty Images
displayImages.altText: England’s goalkeeper Karen Bardsley is sent the wrong way by Aya Miyama, who took an eternity to strike her shot.
displayImages.cleanCaption: England’s goalkeeper Karen Bardsley is sent the wrong way by Aya Miyama, who took an eternity to strike her shot.
displayImages.cleanCredit: Photograph: Mike Hewitt/Fifa via Getty Images

displayImages.caption: Japan players celebrate. They’ve hardly been the dominant team thus far, but they’ve got the first goal at least. Photograph: Geoff Robins/AFP/Getty Images
displayImages.altText: Japan players celebrate.
displayImages.cleanCaption: Japan players celebrate. They’ve hardly been the dominant team thus far, but they’ve got the first goal at least.

displayImages.caption: Soon there’s more controversy at the other end of the pitch as Steph Houghton goes down under a challenge from Saori Ariyoshi. Photograph: Mike Hewitt/Fifa via Getty Images
displayImages.altText: Controversy as Steph Houghton goes down under a challenge from Saori Ariyoshi.
displayImages.cleanCaption: Soon there’s more controversy at the other end of the pitch as Steph Houghton goes down under a challenge from Saori Ariyoshi.
displayImages.cleanCredit: Photograph: Mike Hewitt/Fifa via Getty Images

displayImages.caption: To be fair, it hardly qualified as a ‘challenge’. Houghton went down under minimal contact and quite how or why the referee has called that a penalty is mystery. At worst there was a minor collision of the two players’ feet as Houghton looked to turn. Photograph: Maddie Meyer/Fifa via Getty Images
displayImages.altText: Controversy as Steph Houghton goes down under a challenge from Saori Ariyoshi.
displayImages.cleanCaption: To be fair, it hardly qualified as a ‘challenge’. Houghton went down under minimal contact and quite how or why the referee has called that a penalty is mystery. At worst there was a minor collision of the two players’ feet as Houghton looked to turn.
displayImages.cleanCredit: Photograph: Maddie Meyer/Fifa via Getty Images

displayImages.caption: Fara Williams steps up and slams the resulting spot-kick home. 1-1! Photograph: Mike Hewitt/Fifa via Getty Images
displayImages.altText: Fara Williams steps up and slams a spot-kick home to make it 1-1
displayImages.cleanCaption: Fara Williams steps up and slams the resulting spot-kick home. 1-1!
displayImages.cleanCredit: Photograph: Mike Hewitt/Fifa via Getty Images

displayImages.caption: Well, that’s evened things up. Some will say neither penalty was deserved. England aren’t complaining now.  Photograph: Todd Korol/Getty Images
displayImages.altText: England celebrate
displayImages.cleanCaption: Well, that’s evened things up. Some will say neither penalty was deserved. England aren’t complaining now.

displayImages.caption: In fact, they’re positively delirious. Photograph: Dan Riedlhuber/EPA
displayImages.altText: England celebrate
displayImages.cleanCaption: In fact, they’re positively delirious.

displayImages.caption: Katie Chapman gives Williams a hug. So, it’s all square at half-time. Photograph: Maddie Meyer/Fifa via Getty Images
displayImages.altText: Katie Chapman gives Williams a hug.
displayImages.cleanCaption: Katie Chapman gives Williams a hug. So, it’s all square at half-time.
displayImages.cleanCredit: Photograph: Maddie Meyer/Fifa via Getty Images

displayImages.caption: The second half is a cagey affair. Here, Jill Scott makes ground down the left flank. Photograph: Mike Hewitt/Fifa via Getty Images
displayImages.altText: The second half is a cagey affair, albeit with England twice hitting the crossbar. Here, Jill Scott makes ground down the left flank.
displayImages.cleanCaption: The second half is a cagey affair. Here, Jill Scott makes ground down the left flank.
displayImages.cleanCredit: Photograph: Mike Hewitt/Fifa via Getty Images

displayImages.caption: Toni Duggan rattles the bar with an ambitious strike. That was mighty close. Photograph: Geoff Robins/AFP/Getty Images
displayImages.altText: Toni Duggan rattles the bar with an ambitious strike. That was mighty close.
displayImages.cleanCaption: Toni Duggan rattles the bar with an ambitious strike. That was mighty close.

displayImages.caption: England’s coach Mark Sampson gives out instructions. They’re in the ascendancy as the half wears on. But normal time is fast running out. Photograph: Matthew Lewis/Fifa via Getty Images
displayImages.altText: England’s coach Mark Sampson gives out instructions. They’re in the ascendancy as the half wears on. But normal time is fast running out.
displayImages.cleanCaption: England’s coach Mark Sampson gives out instructions. They’re in the ascendancy as the half wears on. But normal time is fast running out.
displayImages.cleanCredit: Photograph: Matthew Lewis/Fifa via Getty Images

displayImages.caption: Then, two minutes into injury time, England do the unthinkable – they score an own goal. Lauru Bassett, looking to turn away a dangerous cross, toe-pokes the ball up and over her keeper, sending it in off the underside of the crossbar.  Photograph: Todd Korol/Getty Images
displayImages.altText: Then, two minutes into injury time, England do the unthinkable – they score an own goal. Lauru Bassett, looking to turn away a dangerous cross, toe-poked the ball up and over her keeper, sending it in off the underside of the crossbar.
displayImages.cleanCaption: Then, two minutes into injury time, England do the unthinkable – they score an own goal. Lauru Bassett, looking to turn away a dangerous cross, toe-pokes the ball up and over her keeper, sending it in off the underside of the crossbar.

displayImages.caption: A stunning and galling conclusion for England.  Photograph: Ronald Martinez/Getty Images
displayImages.altText: A stunning and galling conclusion.
displayImages.cleanCaption: A stunning and galling conclusion for England.

displayImages.caption: England’s players are distraught. The final whistle has gone and they’re out of the World Cup. Photograph: Mike Hewitt/Fifa via Getty Images
displayImages.altText: England’s players are distraught. The final whistle has gone and they’re out of the World Cup.
displayImages.cleanCaption: England’s players are distraught. The final whistle has gone and they’re out of the World Cup.
displayImages.cleanCredit: Photograph: Mike Hewitt/Fifa via Getty Images

displayImages.caption: No one is more choked up than Laura Bassett. Photograph: Ronald Martinez/Getty Images
displayImages.altText: Laura Bassett cries.
displayImages.cleanCaption: No one is more choked up than Laura Bassett.

displayImages.caption: Shades of Paul Gascoigne all over again. Photograph: Kevin C. Cox/Getty Images
displayImages.altText: Shades of Paul Gascoigne all over again.
displayImages.cleanCaption: Shades of Paul Gascoigne all over again.

cards.title: Football / England coach praises the team's performance despite loss
cards.rawTitle: England coach praises the team's performance despite loss

item.title: England coach praises the team's performance despite losing to Japan
item.trailText: England coach Mark Sampson praises the team's performance after their defeat to holders Japan
item.standFirst: England's coach Mark Sampson praises the team's performance after their defeat in the Fifa Women's World Cup 2015 semi-final against defending champions Japan on Wednesday at the Commonwealth Stadium in Edmonton, Alberta. England lost out to an injury-time own-goal by defender Laura Bassett that sent Japan into the final to face USA. England will now play Germany for third place

stillImage.caption: 620x372 trailpic for England coach praises the team's performance despite losing to Japan  Photograph: guardian.co.uk
stillImage.altText: 620x372 trailpic for England coach praises the team's performance despite losing to Japan
stillImage.cleanCaption: 620x372 trailpic for England coach praises the team's performance despite losing to Japan

displayImages.altText: 620x372 trailpic for England coach praises the team's performance despite losing to Japan
displayImages.cleanCaption: 620x372 trailpic for England coach praises the team's performance despite losing to Japan

cards.title: Football / Sweden jubilant following European U-21 victory over Portugal
cards.rawTitle: Sweden jubilant following European U-21 victory over Portugal

item.title: Sweden jubilant following European Under-21 victory over Portugal
item.trailText: Sweden's Under-21s striker John Guidetti and manager Håkan Ericson give their reactions after Sweden beat Portugal on penalties 4-3
item.standFirst: Sweden's Under-21s striker John Guidetti and manager Håkan Ericson give their reactions after Sweden beat Portugal on penalties 4-3 on Tuesday night in Prague. Guidetti says his side were mentally strong and ran more than every other team in the tournament. Ericson says Sweden were better prepared for the match than Portugal

cards.title: Tennis / The Wimbledon queue: through the eyes of a tournament veteran
cards.rawTitle: The Wimbledon queue: through the eyes of a tournament veteran

item.title: The Wimbledon queue: through the eyes of a tournament veteran
item.trailText: Hundreds of people camp out in order to secure an advantageous spot in the next morning's queue for tickets
item.standFirst: For the first 10 nights of Wimbledon, hundreds of people camp out in the adjacent Wimbledon Park in order to secure an advantageous spot in the next morning's queue for tickets. As many as 1,500 tickets are available for the show courts (Centre, One and Two) each day – and they are in high demand. We set our alarms to 'sunrise' to talk to Richard Hess, who's camping out for the 35th year
